Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186.proposition: At all times relevant to this complaint Defendant was the landlord of the rental premises and owed duties to Plaintiff as tenant, including the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, obligations to provide and maintain premises fit for human habitation, and to remedy conditions that materially interfere with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the premises (see Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186; 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.; Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970); Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant §§ 5.1 et seq.).

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code sets minimum standards of fitness for human habitation and requires landlords to correct conditions that create health hazards, including conditions that promote dampness and mold (see Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111; 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.; Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, §§ 127 et seq., authorizing the State Sanitary Code).

Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every lease, and a landlord’s wrongful interference with a tenant’s possession, or failure to remedy conditions that materially impair the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the property, gives rise to a cause of action for breach of that covenant (see Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970); Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant § 5.1).

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Defendant’s refusal to correct the conditions that cause and perpetuate mold at the premises, and Defendant’s insistence that the problem is solely caused by Plaintiff’s personal habits despite the lack of adequate ventilation and ongoing spread of mold, amounts to a material interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the premises and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and of the landlord’s duty to provide and maintain premises in a habitable condition (see Javins, 428 F.2d 1071; Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984); Park West Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979); Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant § 5.1; Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111; 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.).
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, defines it in terms of providing and maintaining premises that are safe, clean, and fit for human habitation, and holds that substantial defects affecting health and safety constitute a breach. It emphasizes that a landlord’s failure to repair essential facilities after notice, causing conditions that impact a tenant’s health and use of the premises, breaches this duty and justifies full rent abatement and other damages. Although the case does not specifically mention mold, its reasoning clearly supports using similar unhealthy housing conditions (like mold from lack of ventilation) as a material interference with use and enjoyment and a breach of habitability/quiet enjoyment duties.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. … In determining whether there has been a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, courts should inquire whether the claimed defect has an impact on the safety or health of the tenant. … When a landlord, after receiving notice of a defect, fails to repair the facility that is essential to the health and safety of his or her tenant, an award of punitive damages is proper.

Park West Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N..raw_text: Park West Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979)
Park West Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N..proposition: Defendant’s refusal to correct the conditions that cause and perpetuate mold at the premises, and Defendant’s insistence that the problem is solely caused by Plaintiff’s personal habits despite the lack of adequate ventilation and ongoing spread of mold, amounts to a material interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the premises and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and of the landlord’s duty to provide and maintain premises in a habitable condition (see Javins, 428 F.2d 1071; Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984); Park West Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979); Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant § 5.1; Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111; 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.).
Park West Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N..case_name: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell
Park West Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N..support_reasoning: Park West expressly recognizes and applies an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, holding that a landlord has a nondelegable duty to maintain premises free from conditions that materially affect tenants’ health and safety, and that substantial sanitary and infestation conditions constitute a breach warranting rent abatement. Although the facts involve a strike rather than mold, the reasoning squarely supports the broader principle that serious, unremedied conditions harmful to health (like pervasive mold from inadequate ventilation) materially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment and breach the landlord’s habitability obligations. The case thus provides strong doctrinal support for the cited proposition, even if it does not specifically mention mold or the covenant of quiet enjoyment terminology used in the proposition.
Park West Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N..relevant_excerpt: “A residential lease is now effectively deemed a sale of shelter and services by the landlord who impliedly warrants: first, that the premises are fit for human habitation… and, third, that the tenants are not subjected to any conditions endangering or detrimental to their life, health or safety.… [H]e does warrant, however, that there are no conditions that materially affect the health and safety of tenants.… If, in the eyes of a reasonable person, defects in the dwelling deprive the tenant of those essential functions which a residence is expected to provide, a breach of the implied warrant of habitability has occurred.”

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code sets minimum standards of fitness for human habitation and requires landlords to correct conditions that create health hazards, including conditions that promote dampness and mold (see Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111; 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.; Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, §§ 127 et seq., authorizing the State Sanitary Code).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 12.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, §§ 127 et seq.
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 12.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code sets minimum standards of fitness for human habitation and requires landlords to correct conditions that create health hazards, including conditions that promote dampness and mold (see Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111; 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.; Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, §§ 127 et seq., authorizing the State Sanitary Code).

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: The Court may consider persuasive authority from jurisdictions recognizing landlord duties with respect to habitability and mold and awarding tenants relief where landlords fail to address conditions that materially interfere with tenancy; such authorities include cases addressing implied warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment (see also Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (1974) (warranty of habitability principles); Hilder, 478 A.2d 202).
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Green for “warranty of habitability principles” and as part of a body of persuasive authority recognizing landlord duties regarding habitability that can materially interfere with tenancy. Green squarely recognizes a common law implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, ties it to conditions that affect health and safety, and allows tenants to raise breach of that warranty as a defense in unlawful detainer. Although the opinion does not specifically discuss mold, it clearly establishes the broader habitability and quiet-enjoyment-based framework that the proposition invokes.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: “We have concluded that a warranty of habitability is implied by law in residential leases in this state and that the breach of such a warranty may be raised as a defense in an unlawful detainer action. Under the implied warranty which we recognize, a residential landlord covenants that premises he leases for living quarters will be maintained in a habitable state for the duration of the lease. This implied warranty of habitability does not require that a landlord ensure that leased premises are in perfect, aesthetically pleasing condition, but it does mean that ‘bare living requirements’ must be maintained.”
